title: 108_s1633
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Notification and Credit Restoration Act of 2003". The findings section follows. Congress finds that the privacy and financial security of individuals are increasingly at risk due to the widespread collection of personal information by both the private and public sector. Credit card transactions, real estate records, consumer surveys, credit reports, and Internet websites are all sources of personal information for identity thieves. Identity theft is one of the fastest-growing crimes in the United States and has become a major law enforcement challenge in the new economy. Identity theft is a major law enforcement challenge in the new economy, with criminals using stolen personal information for financial crimes. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported being victims of identity theft, costing consumers and the marketplace. Victims of identity theft must contact various law enforcement agencies, credit reporting agencies, and creditors over many years. Government, financial institutions, and credit reporting agencies have a shared responsibility to protect consumer information and assist identity theft victims. The private sector can better protect consumers by improving customer notification, implementing effective fraud alerts, providing greater consumer access to credit reports, and establishing financial identity theft prevention measures. Subtitle B of title V of the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act is amended to include a new section requiring timely notification to customers of unauthorized access to personal information. The term 'breach' in this section refers to the unauthorized acquisition of data compromising the security of personal information held by a financial institution, excluding good faith acquisitions by employees for business purposes. Personal information of a customer of a financial institution includes their first name or initial, last name, and sensitive data like social security number, driver's license number, or credit card information. The financial institution must notify customers affected by a breach of personal information promptly. The financial institution must notify customers and relevant entities like consumer reporting agencies and law enforcement in case of a breach affecting a large number of customers. Other entities that maintain personal information must also be notified. A person maintaining personal information for a financial institution must promptly notify the institution of any breach. Notification must be made upon discovery of the breach, considering law enforcement needs and measures to determine the breach's scope. The financial institution must be promptly notified of any breach to determine its scope and restore information security. Notification may be delayed for law enforcement purposes if it hinders a criminal investigation, but must be provided promptly once the investigation is not compromised. Notification can be in writing to the customer. The financial institution must be promptly notified of any breach to determine its scope and restore information security. Notification to a customer can be provided in writing, electronic form, or as determined by the Federal Trade Commission. The financial institution may use e-mail notice or a conspicuous posting for customer notification in cases where other forms of notification are not feasible or contact information is insufficient. The financial institution may notify customers of a breach through a conspicuous posting on their website, media notification, or other forms as prescribed by the Federal Trade Commission. Each notification to a customer regarding a breach must include a statement informing them that credit reporting agencies have been notified and that their credit report will contain a fraud alert. The financial institution must notify customers of any breach and obtain their authorization for new credit issuance. Compliance is achieved through a comprehensive information security program. The financial institution must have a comprehensive information security program in line with regulatory standards. It should notify customers and consumer reporting agencies of any breach, following internal policies consistent with FTC rules. Civil penalties may apply for non-compliance. Civil penalties may be imposed for violations of the section, allowing customers to seek damages through civil action. Financial institutions in violation may be subject to injunctions. The rights and remedies under this section are additional to those available under applicable law. Compliance with this section is required, and rules of construction apply. Compliance with this section by a financial institution does not violate any laws prohibiting the disclosure of financial information. Financial institutions are not required to disclose information prohibited by law. There is no new recordkeeping obligation imposed by this section. No new recordkeeping obligation is created by this section for financial institutions. SEC. 4. INCLUSION OF FRAUD ALERTS IN CONSUMER CREDIT REPORTS. Section 605 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a definition of fraud alerts as a statement in a consumer's file notifying potential users of possible identity theft. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in a consumer's file to prevent unauthorized credit issuance in the consumer's name. The consumer must provide express preauthorization for any credit extension through designated communication methods. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in a consumer's file to prevent unauthorized credit issuance. Consumer reporting agencies must include a fraud alert promptly upon notification by a financial institution or upon consumer request. Consumer reporting agencies must include a fraud alert in a consumer's file upon request with appropriate evidence of identity theft. Consumer reporting agencies must inform anyone requesting consumer credit information about the presence of a fraud alert in the consumer's file. The Federal Trade Commission will establish regulations for the duration of fraud alerts required by this subsection. Consumer reporting agencies must notify users of consumer credit reports about fraud alerts. Failure to do so is a violation of the section. Users of consumer reports must comply with preauthorization procedures in fraud alerts. Consumer reporting agencies must notify users of consumer credit reports about fraud alerts. Users must comply with preauthorization procedures in fraud alerts. Violation occurs if credit is issued in the name of the consumer to someone else. Adverse actions based solely on fraud alerts are also prohibited. Access to credit reports and scores is addressed in Section 5. No Fee in Certain Cases: Consumer reporting agencies must provide free access to credit reports and scores to consumers upon request. This includes annual access and more frequent access during periods with a fraud alert. Consumer reporting agencies can charge a reasonable fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts to financial institutions. Credit scores must be included in credit reports as per an amendment to the Fair Credit Reporting Act. The Federal Trade Commission must issue final regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment, in consultation with other financial regulatory agencies, to implement the amendments.
